en: Acquired by the museum from the art market in 1924.

This statue is complete, as it was found wrapped in lead, presumably as a form of protection in antiquity. The surface in in good condition, but slightly chipped. Traces of red, yellow, and blue pigment are discernible.
H. with plinth 1.93 m, H. plinth ca. 0.10 m, H. face 0.20 m, W. shoulders 0.55 m
White marble w/ blue-grey streaks (Attic, according to Blmel)
<bibl>Lullies & Hirmer 1979, 39, pls. 18-21</bibl>; <bibl>Lippold 1950, 37 f., pl.10.2</bibl>; E. Buschor, <hi rend="ital">AthMitt</hi> 52 (1927) 212

The pomegranate may be a gift to a deity (in which case this statue might be a votive monument), or merely a funerary indicator. If this statue does represent a deity--as suggested by the polos, as well as the statue's otherwise unsubstantiated nick-name, 'Berlin Goddess'--then the inclusion of the pomegranate would conspire to indicate that it represents Persephone, the daughter of the grain goddess Demeter, and the wife of the underworld god, Hades.
<bibl>Boardman 1978a, fig. 108</bibl>; <bibl>Richter 1968, 39-40 no. 42, figs. 139-46</bibl>; <bibl>Alscher 1954-63, 697 ff.</bibl>; <bibl>Blmel 1964, no. 1 (with full bibliography)</bibl>
Female statue with polos and pomegranate
